Posts.Content: Feb 6, 2012 09:24AM TexasRose wrote: I definitely agree you should go on your trip! I found out I had BC on a Wednesday afternoon. We left three days later to go on a planned cruise. It was going to be two weeks before I could get in to see the BS anyway. I decided I could stay at home and worry or I could go on the cruise and try to enjoy myself. Admittedly, it wasn't my best cruise and I had some moments where I just went to the cabin for a bit, but most of the time I had a lot of fun and walking on beaches is very therapeutic. Looking back, I think I thought it would be my last trip ever so I hated to give it up. It wasn't. I have been on several cruises and trips since and I'm three years out and doing great- having DIEP next week. Go! Have fun! If it is BC, it will be awhile before you can get away. Enjoy it now!
Posts.Title: What would you do? Biopsy scheduled 4 days before vacation... shabby6485 awb

Posts.Title: Starting Chemo June 2009 zuzeee zuzeee

Posts.Content: Jun 30, 2009 03:05PM TexasRose wrote: Dianne, I am currently doing dose dense AC. My last treatment (4th) will be next Tuesday. I actually had to convince my onc to let me do it that way. I am triple negative, so I wanted the most aggressive treatment I could get. It's doable. Not a picnic by any means, but I am getting through it. After AC, I will do 12 weekly Taxol and I am in the clinical trial for Avastin. I've had the Neulasta shot after each AC. My onc does it routinely with dose dense. I haven't had any SE from the Neulasta at all except some very minor bone pain. When I had that, I took the Claritan and Aleve and it cleared right up. The clinical trial nurse told me most people who have a lot of bone pain from the Neulasta shot are tall and thin with long bones. I did have some though and I am far from tall and thin. Hopefully you won't have any side effects from it.   My best advice is to chew on ice chips during AC. I did the first two treatments and had no loss of taste or metallic taste. Forgot to do it for the third treatment and yuck! Nothing has any taste at all. That doesn't help with the nausea any. Like someone else said, the further along I get with AC the more tired I am. But I can live with tired for awhile. I will be glad to see the end of the AC. Yes, you will need to listen to your body and rest when you are tired. I also started taking a Pepcid (the generic) twice a day. That helped and I try to eat small meals more often. I cannot let my stomach get empty. That is nausea trouble for me if I do. This third one has been the hardest by far, but I'm making it. It's easier than I thought and harder than I thought it would be if that makes sense. The time has gone by very quickly. I can't believe I am almost done with AC. I have a long weekend planned for the "good" weekend between AC and Taxol. I usually have about five good days before I have another treatment. I start feeling good Wednesday of the second week. I also feel good the Wednesday following treatment. And yes, I am extra careful during nadir. Actually, I am careful all the time now. I avoid crowds, children and sick people. I don't work, so it's easy for me to do that. I hope that helps you. If you have any more questions, I am happy to try and answer them. It's different for all of us though, so your mileage may vary.    Get some rest and drink a lot of water. Flush that junk out!!! Hugs, Mary

Posts.Content: Apr 25, 2009 11:11AM TexasRose wrote: Hi CoonieRose! Thanks for telling me your experience. I'm sure the anticipation now is getting to me and I will be fine once I get started. And get these tests behind me. I have enjoyed these three weeks since the surgery where I haven't been worried about test results! Seems like we are always nervous about some test result and I don't like that at all. But, yes, I will be fine. I am just ready to get started so I can finished. I am so ready to have my life back!! smerf- you are awesome! Thanks for sharing your experience. I know what you mean about people seeing your boobs. Before surgery, I went to an event with my DH and told a coworker of his that I should just take off my top and show my boobs because everybody else in town had already seen them that day. I don't think she understood. She gave me an odd look. LOL  I pray she never has to find out. I didn't have any positive lymph nodes either, but way back when on the biopsy report there was a line that caused me great concern that said "lymphovascular invasion identified". I asked my BS about it and she glazed over it, but it has caused me some sleepless nights. Oh well, I guess soon I will have a truly complete picture and we go from there. Thanks again everybody for sharing your stories, advice and success. It helps so much!

Posts.Content: Sep 15, 2010 12:22AM TexasRose wrote: I haven't had any scans either and I'm told that is standard practice as I had no lymph node involvement. They tell me that as long as I'm asymptomatic, there is no need. I have to admit that a voice screams in my head, "But I was asymptomatic when I had breast cancer!" My onc also doesn't do tumor markers. He says they are unreliable and an unnecessary stress on the patient for no valid reason. I have no symptoms of anything. But every little ache and pain still scares me to death. I'm only about a year out from treatment ending. I hope it gets easier over time.

It ended up being 2.5 cm. Two maternal aunts have had BC, one of them twice. Both were diagnosed early stage and are NED now. My mom had colon cancer, also diagnosed early and 5 years NED. No other cancer in my immediate family.

Posts.Content: Mar 4, 2009 10:11PM TexasRose wrote: Thanks navygirl. After the diagnosis, it didn't seem possible to go on this cruise. I am so shocked and so terrified. But my husband and I have talked it over and we have decided to definitely go. I need the distraction. We weren't blessed with children although we wanted them very much and travel is my passion since I don't have kids. I told him this might be the last trip we can take for awhile, so we are going. I don't know how I will make it through, but there is no sense staying here and staring at the walls until I know more. A good walk on the beach will do wonders for me and my nurse also thought I should go. The waiting has been so difficult. At least now I have the results and can work towards a plan.

Posts.Title: OTHER SYMPTOMS??? ameron zuzeee

Posts.Content: TexasRose wrote: I just found this message board and have been reading some of the threads. I am 47 years old. I felt a lump with a little pain and tenderness in early February. It took a week to get in to see my PCP. She felt it and sent me for a diagnostic mammogram and ultrasound. It took another week to get in to have those done. After those tests were done, they scheduled me for an ultrasound-guided core needle biopsy. I had that on Thursday the 26th and they said it would be three to five business days before I got the results. This waiting is the hardest thing I have ever lived through.  They took five samples in the biopsy. Four of them didn't hurt at all. One hurt pretty badly and burned. The nurse told me later that was possibly because he might have nicked a blood vessel. I have had some pain and tenderness since the biopsy and I am pretty badly bruised. Other than that, I feel absolutely fine and have no other symptoms. My mom's two sisters both had breast cancer but my mom, my older sister and my grandmother never had it. I am postmenopausal. My periods ended almost two years ago. I am very lucky to have a wonderful, loving and supportive husband and family. (I have no children) But as supportive as they are, they have not been through this and don't understand the waiting and the terror. I was very happy to find this message board as all the others I found were for women who have already been diagnosed. There wasn't much for those of us playing the waiting and praying game. I know the odds are in my favor with the 80% benign rate, but that doesn't make this waiting any easier. I just wanted to say hi and offer hugs and prayers to others who are also waiting. Mary          Mary~~ Left mastectomy/ no recon, SNB, port placement- 4/3/09; DD AC x 4 and Taxol x 12 plus Clinical Trial E5103 (Avastin); Clinical trial S0307 Zometa arm; BRCA Negative; Right PMX & Bilateral flap reconstruction 2/14/2012. Dx 3/4/2009, IDC, 2cm, Stage IIA, Grade 3, 0/5 nodes, ER-/PR-, HER2- Log in to post a reply

I have to have an MRI, blood work and a surgical consult next and then we will decide on a treatment plan. I am so scared...so in shock. I have been surrounded by my husband, my mom, my sister and her partner ever since I got the news. I am very lucky to have them. I have never been so scared in my life.
Posts.Title: Going out of my mind TexasRose momo3esb

Posts.Content: Mar 2, 2009 11:04PM TexasRose wrote: Thank you everybody. It means so much to me to talk with women who totally understand what I'm going through. I was told the other day that no matter what the results are they will most likely want to remove it. It is fairly large and painful. I'm okay with that. I want it gone! I am 47 years old and I have never had surgery before. I've always been very healthy. This is so surreal. And the bizarre thing is we are leaving for a cruise on Saturday. This has been booked for a long time and my husband and I have decided to go ahead and go no matter what the results. I talked about it with the nurse and she said I should go as it will take at least a week and half to two weeks to get an appointment with the surgeon. I am really hoping this is a cruise of celebration. I don't know how I will handle it if the news is bad. I do know that nature, water and sand is very healing and calming for me, so I think it will be good to be on the beach. It's just odd to be packing now. I am having such a hard time concentrating on anything. It is so hard to be so excited and so scared at the same time. I didn't realize there were games here! I better check out this site a little better. Thanks for the hugs, prayers and well wishes.
Posts.Title: Going out of my mind TexasRose momo3esb

Posts.Content: Apr 10, 2009 09:04AM TexasRose wrote: I had mine inserted last Friday during surgery and it's still a little sore, but much better than it was in the first few days. I did just sit up in bed kind of quickly and it hurt and it's still stinging a little a few minutes later, but I think that will wear off. Most of the time now I hardly even notice it. They always have trouble finding veins on me and usually have to do it in my hands. I'll be glad for the port come chemo time.
Posts.Title: Portacath Insertion ugadawg_lover TexasRose

Posts.Content: Nov 18, 2009 12:53AM TexasRose wrote: I admit that I hated my port the whole time I had it- from April 2009 until the end of October when I had it taken out. It was wonderful for chemo. I used the EMLA creme to numb it and access was easy, but it was always uncomfortable. I'd like to say that after awhile the discomfort wore off, but honestly it never did for me. Mine was in a bad place- low on the inside of my right breast. One of the nurses told me once that I didn't have any fat on my chest and that is why it was so uncomfortable. It was right under the skin with nothing to cushion it. It flipped a lot and was just horribly uncomfortable. I didn't have any choice but to keep it though. I did AC and my hospital would not adminster adriamycin without a port because it is so harsh on the veins. I was glad to have it on chemo day, but I hated that thing with a passion. As soon as I finished chemo, I had it taken out. I hope that yours settles down for you and the discomfort passes. As much as I hated it, I wouldn't have gone through chemo without it. It was a very love/hate relationship!

Posts.Title: Heidi Update-it isn't pretty Heidi_Ho zeeka71

Posts.Content: Jan 6, 2012 12:44AM TexasRose wrote: I found a lump and it took a week to get in to see my primary. She ordered a diagnostic mammo- another week waiting on that appt. At the mammo, they decided to do an ultrasound also. After that, they said I needed an ultrasound guided core needle biopsy. That was scheduled for- you guessed it- a week later. After the biopsy they said the results would take five days and they asked if I wanted a phone call with the results "even if they were unfavorable" or did I want to wait for an appt with my primary. I told them to call me, so I found out over the phone. The nurse from the biopsy called me with the results. I'll never forget it. She said, "Unfortunately we did find a little bit of cancer." It was fine for me to hear over the phone. I didn't want to wait on another appt! From the time I first felt my lump (2/8) until I was officially diagnosed (3/4) it was almost a month. Longest month of my life.
Posts.Title: How did you hear biopsy results--phone or appt? frazzledmom schoolmom

Posts.Content: Apr 10, 2009 10:49AM TexasRose wrote: I was kinda freaked when she said she was going to use the hand. I'd never had that before, but it was better than them digging around looking for a vein! I think it hurt less on me. Deen, thanks. I need to head over to the chemo board soon. I have been kind of avoiding it, but I guess the time is getting closer. They don't do chemo at my hospital until at least a month after surgery to give it time to heal first, so I have some time before I start mine. I actually haven't even met with the oncologist yet. My surgery date got changed and moved up by almost three weeks, so that was ahead of schedule and got everything else out of whack. I was supposed to meet with the oncologist before surgery, but that didn't happen.

My surgery was originally scheduled for 4/23 so moving it up was a shock. We found out Tuesday that she could fit me in Friday. I wasn't even sure what I was going to have. My choice was lumpectomy with chemo and rads or mastectomy with chemo. I have chosen mastectomy, but also have second guessed myself a million times. I hadn't broken down since I got the diagnosis. Then a few minutes ago it all hit me and now I can't stop crying. I can't believe that tomorrow my left breast will be gone. I guess I should have known this break down would come.

Posts.Content: Apr 17, 2009 10:38PM TexasRose wrote: Does she know for sure that she could be scheduled for surgery before May 5th? One thing I have learned in all of this is that nothing moves quickly at a hospital. I was diagnosed 3/4 and couldn't even get an appointment to see the breast surgeon until 3/23. We had a cruise scheduled that had been booked for quite some time and we were to leave two days after I got the diagnosis. After much debate, we decided to go ahead and go on our trip. There wasn't anything I could have been doing at home anyway. It wasn't the greatest vacation in the world obviously, but I think it really helped me to calm down and get into fighting mode. I wish her peace whatever she decides.

Posts.Title: How long did you wait for a surgery after you have found a lump? zoegr Raili

Posts.Content: Apr 23, 2009 07:49AM TexasRose wrote: Listen to Barbe and Deb! I know exactly how you feel. A month ago, I was in exactly the same place. We all were at some point. This is scary as hell and you have every right to feel that way. I had never had surgery either. Heck, I had never been sick other than colds and had never spent a night in the hospital before. I have no children, so I had never given birth either. I was so scared of the pain, but it has been very manageable. You can do this! What helps me the most is to take it one thing at a time. I concentrated on the surgery since that was first for me. I didn't give the chemo another thought. After the surgery, I spent the first two weeks healing. Now that it has been almost three weeks since the surgery, I am starting to think about chemo and preparing myself for that. I had a teacher once who would ask us, "How do you eat an elephant? One bite at a time." This is overwhelming and if you let yourself take it all in at once, it's too much. Just take one thing at a time. Your mind is going to go to dark places. That is normal. I believe very much in positive thinking though. When my mind slips into dark places, I do some deep breathing and positive thinking to get myself back on track. Or I come here and read the inspiring stories section. Or I pray. Whatever it takes to get me back to where I need to be to fight this. And I totally agree with Deb about the Xanax. I didn't want to take it. I fought that pretty hard until my breast surgeon pointed out to me that I was making myself anxious about taking anti-anxiety meds. We laughed. I realized she was right and I started taking the pills. I haven't had one since my surgery because I don't need them right now, but I couldn't have gotten through those dark days before the surgery without them. They were a lifeline. Take them. Just having the surgery and knowing the full picture will help so much to take some of the pressure off. I wish you well. You are in my prayers. (((hugs))) Mary
Posts.Title: Going for surgery april 30th...terrified aaronali12 aaronali12
